Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2008 06:12PM C-Babe wrote: Mailman, I had a high oncotype dx score (33) after having an "early-stage" cancer similar to your friends. The tip-off was my high grade (3), and with a high oncotype dx score I am doing the chemo (Taxotere/Cytoxan) for extra protection against recurrence. For me, doing everything possible was written in the score-cards. C-Babe
Posts.Title: Early Stage BC Chemo ? mailman tiff2008

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2008 11:54AM C-Babe wrote: Otter, So sorry that you have to do the chemo.... I was in a similar boat, thinking that I was all set with an early-stage dx and could move on to radiation from surgery, and then the oncotype score hit me right between the eyes. I must say, though, that I was relieved that the choice was clear with my very high score, and I just marched right on toward the chemo after I picked myself up off the floor. Now I'm one tx away from being done with it, knowing that I've done everything I can to beat this thing. Best of luck to you... you have all our support here, as you know... C
Posts.Title: Oncotype score is back--moving to chemo group :( otter jerseymaria

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2008 03:35PM C-Babe wrote: Artsee, I have had NO nausea (knock wood), but have been religious about taking the great meds that they offer (Emend and Kytril on the day of treatment and for the next two days after it). I have had loss of tastebuds, constipation, body aches and fatigue, but all manageable with the meds and a little experience. I expect this 2nd tx to go a bit more smoothly than the first b/c I just know a bit more about what to expect and how my body reacts to the meds. I really felt totally fine for the two weeks leading up to the second treament. Best of luck to you in your decision on treatment... you can do this! C-Babe
Posts.Title: Oncotype results in artsee artsee

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2008 02:42PM C-Babe wrote: Artsee, I also had a horrible oncotype dx score (33) after having a very early-stage, fairly small, clean-margin, no lymph node involvment tumor. I was shocked at first, although like you had the Grade 3 which can indicate the aggressiveness of the tumor and relate closely to the high oncotype result. However, I feel comfortable now that the high score was a DEFINITE indicator that I needed chemo before radiation (had a lumpectomy), so there was no waffling, no decision to make -- I JUST NEEDED TO DO IT. A bit of relief, if you will. I have just finished my second of six treatments and am feeling good that I am doing everything I can to beat this.... best of luck to you.... C-Babe
Posts.Title: Oncotype results in artsee artsee

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2008 03:15PM C-Babe wrote: MLM, Sorry for your diagnosis. You may want to see if there's an "oncology social worker" at your hospital to help you put together some good words and thoughts to tell your son on his terms. I also found the cancercare.org website very helpful for ideas and talking points. You may want to give him chunks of information over time, as he is ready or has questions. Good luck...

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2008 03:00PM C-Babe wrote: Tammy, My situation is somewhat similar. I had a lumpectomy in late December, and went about 2 weeks thinking I was set with just radiation since my path report was pretty decent. Then, whamm-o, the oncotype dx test came back with a 33 recurrence score. So now, chemo for me starting next week. In a way, I'm grateful that the score was 33, making it crystal clear that chemo was the way to go for me. I feel like the decision was made for me, which is easier right now (my husband just died two months ago at age 50, suddenly). Now I have my marching orders! Best of luck to you... I am starting one day after you, on 2/5.... xo C-Babe

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2008 11:42AM C-Babe wrote: Laurel, I find the Claritin helps with the Neulasta se's -- seems to help the bone pain (I had shooting, throbbing pain in my spine when I didn't use it). Perhaps the anti-histamine does it, not sure. The onco nurse was dubious, but said no harm in using it if I feel it works. I take it the day before the shot and for about 4-5 days, and also take Advil -- who knows? Congrats on the half-way mark... you'll be done before you know it! C-Babe

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2008 12:56PM - edited Mar 7, 2008 12:57PM by C-Babe Artsee, I am feeling great now, finding that (like Donnalee) one week after treatment I'm back to being myself. Days 4-6 are the tough ones for me, with body aches, headache, irregularly, and big-time fatigue. Then on day 7-8 I feel like a load has lifted. Things I've found to be critical are: Miralax starting on the day after treatment, Claritin to alleviate the Neulasta bone-pain, and pre-emptive Tylenol or Advil to take care of the headaches and body aches. My appetite has never waned (boo-hoo) although my tastebuds get killed for the week after treatment! The wig is working well, but very itchy for me, too -- I'm using Eucerin Calming Creme on my head and that seems to help. Still, can't wait to whip off the wig at night before bed. Two down, four to go.... C-Babe

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 07:46AM C-Babe wrote: Beegirl, My head is also very sensitive, altho it has calmed down a lot (about 10 days after 2nd tx). I also started shedding around day 14 after the first tx, and by day 17 couldn't wash my hair, so buzzed it. The bristly stubble was VERY sensitive. I sleep on a satin pillow and with a bare head to minimize the pressure at night. I went through another round of shedding (of the bristles) after the 2nd tx -- hair was everywhere in little black spikes! But now, two weeks post-2nd tx, my head is less sensitive and the shedding has slowed again. C-Babe
